I worked at Eli Lilly and Company full-time for more than a year
Pros
-The company itself is great. Good mission, great benefits and pay for Indiana. Treats employees fairly and offers a lot of perks (on-site gym, dentist, daycare, etc.) If you want a stable job this is a good place to work
- Ethical company despite the perception of the industry
-Experience working in a massive, enterprise company with multiple internal organizations. This is good and bad
-Employee experience is designed to build long careers doing multiple roles in different organizations. But with caveats (see cons)
Cons
-USA Marketing is the assembly line of marketing organizations. Each role has a handful of duties that you do over and over again. Very repetitive and unchallenging. Incredibly structured in all ways which make it nearly impossible to try new things or do things differently. 

- Operating environment is a complete mess. So many hand offs, reviews, and people involved in simple tasks. Some of this is due to regulatory requirements and work volume, but mainly the company/leadership's inability to solve any problems. It adds more people to a workflows instead of making true improvements. Your job is figuring out how to get things done within Lilly vs. meeting customer needs through marketing

- Marketing culture is subtly bad. Everyone is nice, respectful and very smart, but to the point of arrogance. A lot of thinkers and very few do-ers. The 'Lilly-only' approach neglects and excludes outside ideas for marketing execution, structure, strategies, etc.

- If you're an experienced hire coming into the company your experience will not be valued. They'll tell you this isn't true but it definitely is 

- There is career progression but you have to play 'the Lilly game.' If you don't follow a standard career path your likelihood of moving up is low. You have to fit into a defined box that looks like other employees e.g. move from Sales into an LMA role into Marketing. The process of applying to internal jobs is incredibly political and not transparent. You have to know the hiring manager, understand the exact pain points of the brand, get letters of recommendation internally, get senior leader endorsement. None of this is DOCUMENTED. It's embedded within the culture and is an unwritten expectation. There are so many qualified people that don't get jobs they deserve

- Undergoing a re-org designed to improve marketing operating environment. This has been a huge mess. Not enough fat was cut and there is the same number of people and pass-through groups. It's ineffective without wholly new processes and technology. Lilly is adopting Agile and martech, but its ability to execute is historically bad so don't expect true change. The 'prioritized' re-hire period of the re-org was a joke and put many talented people into suboptimal roles

- All senior leaders are career Lilly employees and can't conceptualize new ideas/structures or take necessary risks to drive change
Advice to Management
Simplify operations, reduce barriers in tactic production, and bring in outside thinking at the Sr. Director level and up. Take a customer-first approach to marketing vs. product.

Safety is a good thing here but I have witnessed a supervisor driving a forklift without a safety belt on just hours after a safety meeting where they told everyone "it is company policy to always use proper Personal protective equipment including seatbelts while driving to forklifts". My boss was up over 8 feet crawling around on equipment where he should have on fall protection, before I could say anything he mentioned it was in my best interest to not say anything. Some areas are more inviting to diversity than others. I have witnessed what I believe to be acts of age discrimination. Example of age discrimination: younger workers were told that if they got a degree they would be promoted, in that meeting was an older guy that had the needed degree but was not promoted he later retired without the promotion, in attendance was my supervisor, my manager and my director. They will bate and switch on you to get whatever they need. When I had health issues I was told that if my performance didn't improve that I would be fired. I have witnessed managers bragging about firing 30+ year employees and how they did that in the past. They will replace you with a new younger "you" quickly and not care one bit about any health issues you have. They have a goal of zero human errors per year in the insulin manufacturing areas. if you have a human error they can dock your raise and your bonus. I was introduced to my lab partner that had went 17 years without making a single human error. You do the math. review_title: Blatant and Obvious Reverse Discrimination in Lilly Diabetes
pros:
Sales Team is full of great people
Associate-level talent is generally pretty strong
Job Stability
cons:
The reverse discrimination at Lilly Diabetes has reached a level where something must be done. Promotions no longer go to people who have earned them, but instead go to "diverse" candidates who are willing to move to Indiana. They don’t even need to actually be “diverse”; they just need to look like they are. In fact, the sales team receives videos saying things like, "We need to promote people who aren't necessarily ready for positions in order to increase the diversity of our leadership team." 

This practice is not only discriminatory; it is also disrespectful to the diverse people who have rightfully earned and deserve a promotion – who are many. These people now have to feel embarrassed that their coworkers believe their success is the result the company's meddling and not their own hard work. Diabetes Leadership is being discriminatory to the very constituency they are claiming to support. By promoting employees into jobs they aren’t ready for, they are actually increasing the likelihood that these people quit due to the pressure to succeed in a position they aren’t yet ready to handle.

It has gotten to a point where over the past 12 months, I can think of many "diverse" people who were hired into jobs they in no way deserve and a corresponding group of high-potential, white males that have quit as a result of realizing that Lilly Diabetes is not a meritocracy where promotions go to those who deserve them, but a place where those in power make decisions based on other factors.

What about HR you say. Shouldn't they be working as a check and balance to this kind of discriminatory social justice initiative? After all, Lilly is a publicly held company with a fiduciary responsibility to its shareholders. It’s not an NGO with a stated mission of increasing diversity at the highest levels of corporate leadership. Sadly, HR is either complicit or willfully turning a blind eye to what has - at this point - become a very clear trend. 

The evidence is manifest. The demographic profile of the people who are quitting is exactly the same -- high potential white men who, by and large, have leadership experience from the sales team. At what point does HR get actually do something to take the business units' hiring practices back? How many top people need to quit before they take notice? Is it true that Lilly no longer needs to hire and promote the “best and brightest”?

I guess time will tell. As for me, I am actively looking for a way to get out of here and to go to a company where my hard work will be rewarded. Lilly Diabetes isn’t a good place to work for either minorities or non-minorities. Good luck getting to your goal in 2020 without the best talent you can find.

pros: Great benefits. Very good overall compensation. Smart, dedicated colleagues. Beautiful, comfortable work environment.
cons:
A poisonous atmosphere of mistrust, fearfulness and egos makes it nearly impossible for real issues to get raised and solved. Heavy-handed management and central decision making stunts creativity. A soulless and soul-sucking golden palace of status quo.
Advice to Management
Stop treating your employees like fungible resources. Stop measuring every employee against some imaginary standard. Instead, invest in their potential. Train your managers how to discover employees' unique gifts and give them challenges that unlock and develop those gifts. Employee engagement and productivity and innovation will follow.
